_exec_summary.SummaryText:
PURPOSE FOR RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN RESUBMISSION / UPDATE

Stolthaven Houston Inc. is updating the facility's Risk Management Plan (RMP) in January of 2011 to revise the operating scenario for a regulated toxic substance to be handled in a newly covered process at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  Note that this RMP regulated substance is already present at the facility above the applicable threshold quantity.  The specific changes associated with this RMP update include:

- Updating the RMP pursuant to the requirements of 40 CFR 68, Section A? 68.190(b)(4), due to Stolthaven Houston Inc. commencing the storage and associated parcel shipments of Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) from the facility's D Tank Farm in existing Low-Pressure Storage Tank D-30-10 above the threshold quantity for TDI of 10,000-pounds.  Stolthaven Houston currently stores TDI in two other existing Low-Pressure Tanks also located in the facility's D Tank Farm.  

- Updating the estimated residential populations living within the predicted 'distance-to-endpoint' for the various Worst-Case Release scenarios associated with this RMP based on the Landview 6 software created by the EPA, the Census Bureau, the United States Geological Survey (USGS), and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Association (NOAA).  

- Minor RMP data element updates based on revisions to Stolthaven Houston's 'Process Safety and Risk Management Program Manual' and the 'Local Training Manual (LTM)' made since the previous RMP update submitted in March of 2010.  


A? 68.155(a):  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

At Stolthaven Houston Inc. we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes related to bulk chemical storage and distribution in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning programs to protect the environment and to ensure the safety of our employees as well as the citizens of the surrounding communities.

This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that Stolthaven Houston Inc. has designed and implemented, including:

- A description of our facility and the substances regulated by 40 CFR Part 68 that are currently handled on-site in stationary sources above their corresponding threshold quantities

- An overview of our accidental release prevention programs

- A five-year accident history for significant accidental releases from processes covered by EPA's RMP rule

- An overview of our emergency response programs

- An overview of improvements at the facility implemented to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, the environment, and company assets

- Detailed information (i.e. data elements) about our Risk Management Program


A? 68.155(b):  STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

Stolthaven Houston Inc. owns and operates an existing bulk liquids storage and distribution terminal located on the north side of the Houston Ship Channel near Channelview in eastern Harris County, Texas.  The facility currently consists of 148 large above-ground storage tanks, four truck loading/unloading racks (Racks T-3, T-4, T-5, and T-6), three rail car loading/unloading racks (Racks R-1, R-2, and R-3), one barge dock (Barge Dock C), and a finger pier jetty equipped with two separate marine vessel berths (Ship Dock 2/3).  A biological waste water treatment plant and various air pollution control devices are also operated on-site.  Bulk liquid products are received into the Stolthaven Houston Terminal by various modes of transportation cargo containers that can include tank trucks, ISO tank containers, flexi-bags, rail tank cars, barges, and marine parcel tankers (i.e. ships).  The received liquid products are stored on-site according to customer-specified requirements, and are subsequently transferred off-site through one or more of the above-referenced transpor

tation modes.  Stolthaven Houston Inc. also performs direct product transfers between marine vessels and rail tank cars with no intermediate storage.  Similarly, land-based intermodal (IMO) transfers directly between tank trucks, ISO tank containers, flexi-bags, and rail tank cars are also performed routinely at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  Note that Stolthaven Houston Inc. does not perform any chemical processing or chemical manufacturing operations on-site, and the company does not own nor ultimately control any of the bulk liquid products that are stored or otherwise handled at the facility.

The following chemicals presently handled at Stolthaven Houston Inc. have been identified by the EPA as having the potential to cause significant off-site consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release:

Regulated Toxic Substances (2):

Toluene Diisocyanate (CAS Number 26471-62-5) &
Vinyl Acetate Monomer (CAS Number 108-05-4)

Regulated Flammable Substances (2):

Normal Pentane (CAS Number 109-66-0),
Isopentane (CAS Number 78-78-4), &
Normal Pentane (> 45%) / Isopentane (< 55%) Blends

TDI and VAM currently represent the only two RMP regulated substances at Stolthaven Houston Inc. that are present above their corresponding threshold quantities at all times.  Pentane, Isopentane, and Mixed Pentane Blends are periodically transloaded directly between land-based transportation containers with no intermediate on-site product storage.  As a result, the above-referenced Pentanes are not always present on-site at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  

Our training and accidental release prevention programs in combination with our Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) and contingency planning efforts help us effectively manage the potential hazards posed to our employees, the public, and the environment through the storage and/or transfer of the above-referenced RMP regulated chemicals.

TOLUENE DIISOCYANATE STORAGE AND TRANSFERS

Stolthaven Houston Inc. currently sto

res Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI) in two 15,000-barrel nominal capacity above-ground storage tanks:  Low-Pressure Storage Tanks D-15-21 and D-15-22.  Tank D-15-21 has a fill-restricted maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 5,127,000-pounds (510,689-gallons).  Tank D-15-22 also has a fill-restricted maximum TDI storage capacity of approximately 5,131,000-pounds (511,022-gallons).  Periodic direct transfers of TDI from marine vessels into rail tank cars is also performed at Stolthaven Houston Inc. with no intermediate product storage.  Stolthaven Houston Inc. currently has over 15-years of experience in the storage and handling of TDI.  

Stolthaven Houston Inc. proposes to commence the storage of TDI in a third above-ground storage tank at the facility:  Low-Pressure Storage Tank D-30-10.  Storage Tank D-30-10 is an existing low-pressure tank that has a fill-restricted maximum TDI working capacity of approximately 11,000,800-pounds (1,095,693-gallons).  TDI storage is currently projected to commence in Tank D-30-10 during the second half of January 2011.  

As part of the changes associated with this RMP update, significant modfications were performed such that TDI can be safely and efficiently handled in Low-Pressure Storage Tank D-30-10 at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  These recent changes include:

- Rerouting and connecting the Storage Tank D-30-10 lateral line into Stolthaven Houston's existing TDI common marine transfer line in D-Manifold, which currently services Low-Pressure Storage Tanks D-15-21 and D-15-22 while also in TDI service

- Relocating the existing pump for Storage Tank D-30-10 from D-Manifold such that it will now be located adjacent to the tank itself within D Tank Farm

- Rerouting the rail car and tank truck product transfer lines for Low-Pressure Storage Tank D-30-10 such that they will now run directly between the storage tank and G-Manifold, thereby bypassing D-Manifold completely

- Installation of a new radar gauge, high-level al

arm, and ambient air dessicant system at Storage Tank D-30-10

- Installation of two new carbon adsorption canisters for TDI located (1) in-line with the existing storage tank vapor line to the facility's Tank Farm Vent Flare and (2) at Truck Rack T-6

- Installation of two new TDI loading meters at Rail Rack R-2

- Installation of a new mineral oil heating system for Storage Tank D-30-10 while in TDI service

- Installation of a new gas-seal and associated monitoring system for the existing Storage Tank D-30-10 land system pump located in G Manifold, and

- Insulating and heat tracing the Storage Tank D-30-10 lateral line as well as the associated rail car and tank truck product transfer lines

- Installation of new TDI product loading hoses at Rail Rack R-2, Truck Rack T-6, and Ship Dock 2/3

Stolthaven Houston's contracted customer for TDI storage in Tank D-30-10 is a signatory to the American Chemistry Council's (ACC) Responsible Care program and its Distribution Code of Management Practice.  As a result, they have been involved in the above-referenced modifications associated with the forthcoming storage of TDI in Low-Pressure Storage Tank D-30-10.  Note that sometime after March of 2011 Stolthaven Houston tentatively expects to release Storage Tank D-15-21 from TDI service for a planned product change performed at the request of Stolthaven's contracted customer.  This change in service to a chemical that is not regulated under the RMP rules will significantly reduce the maximum potential TDI inventory on-site at the facility.    

The Tank D-30-10 TDI storage project was discussed in a Stolthaven Houston Supervisors meeting held on December 8, 2010, and in separate Operations Department meetings held on December 9, 2010 and December 14, 2010.  Additional training for field personnel related to the specific modifications recently completed to make Tank D-30-10 suitable for TDI storage was performed during "Safety Only" meetings conducted on December 23 and 28,

2010 by Stolthaven Houston's Engineering Department.  The initial pre-start up safety review (PSSR) was conducted on December 16, 2010 with representatives present from all affected departments;  a final systems walk-through was conducted on January 19, 2011 prior to comissioning Tank D-30-10 into TDI service.  As a result of the PSSR, certain valve actuators in D-Manifold were relocated such that they were made more easily accessible to field operations personnel, and the insulation on certain sections of TDI piping was also improved.

ISO & NORMAL PENTANE INTERMODAL TRANSFERS

Isopentane, n-Pentane, and iso/normal pentane blends are periodically transloaded directly between land-based transportation containers (i.e. tank trucks, ISO tank containers, and rail tank cars) at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal's Rail Rack R-2 and Truck Rack T-6  with no intermediate product storage.  Vapors generated during these transfer operations are directed to the terminal's Tank Farm Vent Flare for pollution control.  

VINYL ACETATE MONOMER STORAGE AND TRANSFERS

Storage Tank P-50-5 is an existing IFR tank at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal with a maximum working capacity of approximately 50,142-barrels, which corresponds to a maximum VAM storage capacity of approximately 16,400,000-pounds.  Tank P-50-5, which represents the facility's worst-case VAM release scenario, was placed into VAM service for the first time on February 25, 2010.  VAM is received into this tank via barge delivery using a dedicated marine dock line.  Product is stored and then shipped outbound according to customer requirements via marine parcel tankers that load at Stolthaven Houston's existing Ship Dock 2/3.  VAM may also be transferred periodically directly from barges to rail tank cars with no intermediate product storage.

As a result of the 2010 VAM storage project for Tank P-50-5, piping modifications were completed in various facility manifolds and at Tank P-50-5 to eliminate the use of hoses in VAM s

ervice to the greatest extent possible within the terminal.  A VAM filter-pot was also installed adjacent to the storage tank.  Stolthaven Houston's permanent, stationary fire-water protection systems in the immediate area of Tank P-50-5 were also upgraded to provide additional cooling water as-needed in the event of an emergency incident involving any of the the facility's flammable or combustible liquid storage tanks in close proximity.  Existing portable water delivery systems also remain available should they be needed in the event of an emergency.

Employee training related to the specifics of VAM storage and transfer at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal was first conducted in December of 2008 and then again in April of 2009 in preparation of receiving this RMP regulated substance into the facility's A Tank Farm in 2009.  Although current facility employees have been trained and are experienced in the procedures necessary to safely handle VAM, additional safety training related specifically to VAM storage in P Tank Farm was conducted in December of 2009.  Specific topics covered during this employee review of safe VAM handling procedures included, but were not limited to, the following information:  product transfer modes and affected facility equipment, VAM technical and physical properties, inhibitor specifications and periodic verification, nitrogen blanketing to maintain low oxygen levels, special product hazards and warnings, required personal protective equipment (PPE), and environmental/regulatory considerations.  VAM has been successfully handled at Stolthaven Houston Inc. since April of 2009 without significant incident.  

   
A? 68.155(c):  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of hazardous chemicals.  Our management systems address each of the key features of successful prevention programs, including:

- Process Safety Information (PSI)

- Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

- ISO 9001: 2000 Certified Quality Management System (QMS)

- Employee Training / Local Training Manual (LTM)

- Mechanical Integrity Program

- Spill Containment

- Management of Change (MOC)

- Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)

- Vapor Control Systems

- Compliance Audits

- Formal Incident Investigation

- Employee Participation Program

- Hot Work / Safe Work Permits

- Departmental / Safety Meetings

- Facility Safety Committee

- Emergency Response Team (ERT)

- Emergency / Incident Response Contractors

The above-referenced elements of our prevention program work together to help prevent accidental chemical releases.  Our company and our employees are committed to the standard that these management systems set for the way we conduct business, and we have specific accountabilities and controls in place to ensure that we meet our own high standards for accident prevention.


A? 68.155(d):  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

During the preceding five (5) years there have been no accidental releases from RMP covered processes at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal which resulted in death, injuries, or significant property damage on-site.  Similarly, there have been no accidental releases from any RMP covered processes which resulted in known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

All incidents and non-routine product releases at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal are formally investigated as part of our facility's ISO Quality Management System (QMS) to identify and correct the root cause(s) of any events, and to implement appropriate corrective actions for continuous process improvement.


A? 68.155(e):  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

We maintain an integrated contingency plan, which consolidates the various federal, state, and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively pro

tecting our employees, the public, the environment, and company assets during potential emergency situations.  Furthermore, we coordinate our action plan with the community emergency response plan and the North Channel Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  Stolthaven Houston Inc. is also an active member of Channel Industries Mutual Aid (CIMA).

An Emergency Action Plan (EAP) is maintained which provides guidelines for responding to various emergencies such as fires, hazardous material spills, personal injuries, severe weather events, and property damage that may occur at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal.  


A? 68.155(f):  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The following is a list of procedures implemented at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal to prevent and/or better respond to accidental chemical releases:

- PHA and adaptation of PHA recommendations

- Continuous improvement through the facility's ISO 9001: 2000 Certified Quality Management System (QMS)

- Employee Suggestion / Experienced Feedback Program

- Regular safety meetings with Stolthaven Houston operations employees and contract 
personnel working in the Stolthaven Houston Terminal

- Facility Safety Committee

New fire water delivery monitors were installed in 2010 to improve coverage for flammable and combustible liquids potentially stored in D and P Tank Farms.  Additional modifications to the terminal's D Tank Farm fire-fighting systems are planned for 2011, including additional delivery monitors and larger capacity headers.  New capital budget projects planned to improve safety and emergency reponse at the Stolthaven Houston Terminal during 2011 include the addition of an 80-gallon fire-fighting foam tank to the facility's Quick-Attack Truck No. 2 (QA-2), additional surveillance cameras to be installed around the terminal's piping manifolds and truck loading/unloading areas, additional Personal Pretective Equipment (PPE) for the company's emergency response team personnel, upgrades to the marin

e fire-fighting foam delivery systems, additional secondary containment for Stolthaven Houston's Q Tank Farm, and the installation of automatic emergency shutdown systems on certain storage tanks handling highly toxic chemicals.
